@article{10.1145/226643.226644,
author = {Selman, Bart and Kautz, Henry},
title = {Knowledge compilation and theory approximation},
year = {1996},
issue_date = {March 1996},
publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery},
address = {New York, NY, USA},
volume = {43},
number = {2},
issn = {0004-5411},
url = {https://doi.org/10.1145/226643.226644},
doi = {10.1145/226643.226644},
abstract = {Computational efficiency is a central concern in the design of knowledge representation systems. In order to obtain efficient systems, it has been suggested that one should limit the form of the statements in the knowledge base or use an incomplete inference mechanism. The former approach is often too restrictive for practical applications, whereas the latter leads to uncertainty about exactly what can and cannot be inferred from the knowledge base. We present a third alternative, in which knowledge given in a general representation language is translated (compiled) into a tractable formallowing for efficient subsequent query answering.We show how propositional logical theories can be compiled into Horn theories that approximate the original information. The approximations bound the original theory from below and above in terms of logical strength. The procedures are extended to other tractable languages (for example, binary clauses) and to the first-order case. Finally, we demonstrate the generality of our approach by compiling concept descriptions in a general frame-based language into a tractable form.},
journal = {J. ACM},
month = mar,
pages = {193224},
numpages = {32},
keywords = {Horn clauses, efficient reasoning methods, knowledge compilation, knowledge-base optimization, query evaluation, theory approximation}
}

relationTypes.name: No Poly, Unknown Quasi
relationTypes.label: \not\leq_p, ?\leq_q
relationTypes.description: No polynomial transformation exists but quasi-polynomial might.

relationTypes.name: Both Unknown
relationTypes.label: ?\leq_p, ?\leq_q
relationTypes.description: Unknown whether any sub-exponential transformation exists

smoothness.label: Smoothness
smoothness.description: All disjuncts mention the same variables

read-once.label: Read-Once
read-once.description: Each variable appears at most once on any path

CO.label: Consistency
CO.description: Check if the formula is satisfiable

VA.label: Validity
VA.description: Check if the formula is a tautology

CE.label: Clausal Entailment
CE.description: Check if a clause is entailed

IM.label: Implicant
IM.description: Find an implicant of the formula

EQ.label: Equivalence
EQ.description: Check logical equivalence of two formulas

SE.label: Sentential Entailment
SE.description: Check if one formula entails another

CT.label: Model Counting
CT.description: Count the number of satisfying assignments

matrix.description: This is an implicit relationship. PICNF in polynomial time. If CNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then PIDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIDNF being no-quasi.
This is an implicit relationship. IPDNF in polynomial time. If CNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.
This is an implicit relationship. MODSDNF in polynomial time. If CNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $CNF$ is a subset of $NNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, d-DNNF is a subset of DNNF, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.
This is an implicit relationship. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from d-DNNF to NNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $DNF$ is a subset of $DNNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
This is an implicit relationship. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from DNF to NNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $DNNF$ is a subset of $NNF$, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, FBDD is a subset of d-DNNF, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.
This is an implicit relationship. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from FBDD to DNNF.

This is an implicit relationship. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from FBDD to NNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $IP$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
This is an implicit relationship. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to DNNF.

This is an implicit relationship. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to NNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $MODS$ is a subset of $d-DNNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $MODS$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
This is an implicit relationship. MODS transforms to DNF in polynomial time. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to DNNF.

This is an implicit relationship. MODS transforms to DNF in polynomial time. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to NNF.
This is an implicit relationship. CNFNNF in polynomial time. If NNFDNF in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.

This is an implicit relationship. CNFNNF in polynomial time. IPDNF in polynomial time. If NNFIP in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.

This is an implicit relationship. CNFNNF in polynomial time. MODSDNF in polynomial time. If NNFMODS in quasipolynomial time, then CNFDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts CNFDNF being no-quasi.

This is an implicit relationship. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to d-DNNF.

This is an implicit relationship. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to DNNF.
This is an implicit relationship. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to FBDD.

This is an implicit relationship. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD$_<$ to NNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $OBDD_<$ is a subset of $OBDD$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $PI$ is a subset of $CNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

Consider the $CNF$ formula $\Sigma_n= igwedge_{i=0}^{n-1}(x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1})$. This formula is in prime implicates form and each clause in $\Sigma_n$ is an essential prime implicate of it. Hence its negation $
eg\Sigma_n\in PI$.

Since the work of Quine, we know that the number of essential prime implicants of a formula is a lower bound on the number of terms that can be found in any $DNF$ representation of it. However, since $\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicates, $
eg\Sigma_n$ has $2^n$ prime implicants, so any $DNF$ representation of $
eg\Sigma_n$ must have at least $2^n$ clauses.
This is an implicit relationship. IPDNF in polynomial time. If PIIP in quasipolynomial time, then PIDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIDNF being no-quasi.
This is an implicit relationship. MODSDNF in polynomial time. If PIMODS in quasipolynomial time, then PIDNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts PIDNF being no-quasi.
This is an implicit relationship. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time. CNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from PI to NNF.
This is an implicit relationship. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to d-DNNF.

This is an implicit relationship. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to DNNF.
As defined by Darwiche 2002, $OBDD$ is a superset of $FBDD$. Therefore a polynomial time transformation is trivial.

This is an implicit relationship. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to NNF.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: This formula helps separate PI from IP, among other important separations.

separatingFunctions.name: Parity function
separatingFunctions.description: $O_n = \bigoplus_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i$ has linear size $OBBD_<$ representations but exponential size CNF and DNF representations.

separatingFunctions.name: $OR_n = \bigvee_{i=1}^{n} x_i$
separatingFunctions.description: Separates languages that compactly represent disjunctions from those that cannot.
